title: Sentimental gems: 5 luminaries share their most treasured jewellery
text:
Gherardo Felloni

Creative director of luxury accessories brand Roger Vivier

Gherardo Felloni wearing his favourite piece, a necklace featuring two diamond pins from the late 19th century.

Italian-born Gherardo Felloni loves beautiful things.

“I look for it everywhere,” he says. “I find beauty in many things that most people find ugly, for example, because I think this is a question of balance and mix.”

A trained tenor and self-described eclectic, the creative director of Roger Vivier has collected jewellery, much of it 19th century and French, for more than 15 years. He also has a thing for cameo jewellery.

His collection has its own room in his Paris home, while some pieces are on loan to the Museum of Jewellery in Vicenza, Italy. He wears his jewellery regularly, often sporting elegant necklaces or chokers. “I don’t just wear jewels for a dinner party. I wear them even on the Métro,” Felloni told The New York Times after being appointed creative director of Roger Vivier in March 2018.

Felloni’s favourite piece is a necklace that features two diamond pins created by the famous French jeweller and collector Henri Vever in the late 19th century.

But his most sentimental item of jewellery is the very first necklace he bought. Purchased from the Milan jewellery store Gioielleria Pennisi, “it is very important to me because it influenced all the jewellery choices I have made since”, he says.

Roger Vivier is Felloni’s “dream job”. The glamorous Parisian accessories label has shod the likes of Elizabeth Taylor and the infamous Duchess of Windsor, while Catherine Deneuve famously wore the Vivier Belle de Jour shoe in the 1967 film of the same name.

“I think every shoe designer looks at the history of fashion to get inspiration. And for me Roger Vivier has always been like a mentor. He’s always been someone who made the most beautiful things ... when I was at the beginning of my career, I used to say, one day I would love to work at Roger Vivier.”

Jen Rubio

Co-founder and chief brand officer of Away

Jen Rubio with her celebratory eternity ring from Carbon & Hyde. Daniela Spector

It’s been a big year for the American luggage start-up Away, founded by Jen Rubio and Steph Korey in 2015, valued at $US1.4 billion ($2.4 billion) in May and now shipped to 40 countries including Australia.

Rubio’s favourite piece of jewellery, a Rainbow eternity ring set with 18 coloured sapphires from Los Angeles jewellers Carbon & Hyde, celebrates that success.

“I bought it a few years ago,” she says. “Things with Away had started to pick up, I was in a new relationship, I’d just moved into a new place and I remember being drawn to this ring because it was so happy.

“It’s a significant piece of jewellery, but also so light and fun, and it just reminds me of that time.”

For Rubio, jewellery is about emotions. “You just have to love it,” she says.

“Many of my pieces have a story or were a gift from someone important, and many others are just beautifully designed and remind me of a specific time in my life. If you don’t look at your jewellery and feel something, then it feels like a waste to me.”

Justin O’Shea

Founder of menswear label SSS World Corp

Justin O'Shea at Paris Fashion Week in January, wearing his favourite piece, a pinky ring, on his right hand. Getty

At his spring 2020 show in Paris in June, Australian designer Justin O’Shea sent his models down the runway wearing giant pearl necklaces.

The tattooed street-style star, who grew up in Nhulunbuy in the Northern Territory, has a passion for pearls.

“It’s a long story but I made a trip to Tahiti to buy pearls when I was about 28. I had a random dream to be a pearl trader. Anyway, it led me to meet the Paspaley family [of Paspaley pearls], which is the most incredible company.

“The thought of something so precious that grows naturally in the ocean, impossible to predict, is a beautiful one.

“I always wear a gold mother-of-pearl earring which we designed together,” he says, and he bought his grandmother a Paspaley bracelet for her 90th birthday.

O’Shea’s most treasured piece is a pinky ring made eight years ago by his good friend the Sikh American designer Waris Ahluwalia of House of Waris. Fine Jewellery.

“It was my most elaborate birthday present to myself,” he says. “It’s a large emerald-cut ruby from Rajasthan, set in a 24-carat gold ‘brutalist’ setting, beautifully engraved with my initials on one side and a palm tree on the other and surrounded with a decorative pattern similar to what you would see on old Winchester rifles.”

Hiromi Yu

Managing director of Marais

Hiromi Yu says she never leaves the house without hoop earrings. Supplied

Jewellery completes an outfit, says Hiromi Yu, founder of the luxury Melbourne boutique Marais, which stocks high-end labels including Alexander McQueen, Loewe, Balenciaga and Celine.

While Yu wears both fine and costume jewellery during the day to “enhance” her outfits and never leaves the house without hoop earrings, her favourite piece actually belongs to her father. It’s a “rather genderless” rose gold ring set with a pink-orange padparadscha sapphire from Sri Lanka.

“He’s got exquisite taste in jewellery,” she says.

At the moment Yu is mad for Grecian chokers, because “they complete a look quite irresistibly”. Her favourite era for jewellery was “the golden age” of ancient Greece. Why? “Plenty of hoop earrings.”
description: Whether a gift from a loved one or a gift to oneself, the true value of a prized piece goes way beyond the price tag.
